awd_titl_txt: Analysis and Control Theory for Moving Boundary and Nonlinear Phenomena in Interactive Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
The theme of this research project is to conduct mathematical and computational studies on classes of partial differential equations (PDE) with moving boundaries. The first part of the project mathematically describes the phenomenon of acoustic sound waves within a chamber whose flexible walls are allowed to move freely as time evolves. For such acoustic wave dynamics, the goal is to determine which pre-assigned chamber geometries will give rise to an interior acoustic field that is as "quiet" as possible. That is to say, because of the analytically pre-determined chamber configuration, the acoustic pressure will be minimized and external noise optimally reduced. The second part of the project focuses on structure-fluid interactions as they occur in nature and engineering, for example the nucleus of a cell interacting with the cellular cytoplasm. In this example, the wall of the nucleus might be described by structural PDE, and the cytoplasm mathematically modeled by fluid flow PDE.  The goal of the project is to develop and analyze more realistic models that comprise both fluid and structure PDE dynamics. 

The first part of the project will address the feasibility of stabilizing interior acoustic wave dynamics on a time-evolving bounded domain through the means of prescribing, in advance, the evolution of the geometry. That is, as time gets large, the prescribed moving boundary feedback law should cause the acoustic wave solutions to either decay or approach a certain set of finite energy states. Since the associated wave energy is majorized by wave boundary trace quantities that resemble velocity feedback mechanisms, this "geometry-control" problem might be viewed as a moving boundary analog to Neumann boundary stabilization of the wave equation on a fixed domain. The second part of the project will consider linear and nonlinear structure-fluid PDE models in which the structural components are mathematically modeled by physically relevant but quite complex Reissner-Mindlin-Timshenko (RMT) plate systems. By decoupling these structure-fluid dynamics, the associated pressure variables are eliminated in a nonstandard manner, intrinsic to the coupling mechanisms in place. Having resolved the well-posedness, the study will consider an associated optimal control problem that will reveal certain ocular dynamics. In addition, the question of global exact controllability for nonlinear von Karman plate dynamics will be investigated. The objective is to establish the exact steering property with respect to finite energy states of arbitrary size, not only target states within a small neighborhood of the origin. This control process will be simulated numerically and the dependence of the controllability time on the size of the initial and target states will be examined.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
During the Project Terms, the PI's have obtained the outcomes described below.

 The PI's have considered the oscillations of vibrating plates, in the absence of rotational inertia, acted upon by nonlinear boundary dissipation.  They invoked recent techniques in the long time behavior analysis of vibrating thin plates to show that the entire infinite dimensional system can be reduced to a finite dimensional system asymptotically. Since a precise, longtime analysis for Berger plate equations was largely absent from the literature, it is conceivable that our work could become a blueprint from an engineering point of view- especially in the construction of durable bridges which can be mathematically descibed by Berger plate equations.

 In addition, the PI's considered the mixed finite element method (FEM) to numerically approximate the solutions of a certain fluid-structure interaction PDE model, a model in which the (distinct) fluid and structure domains have the same dimensionality. In contrast to earlier works where only numerical experiments were provided, we particularly addressed the main issue for convergence of the given FEM, by showing the existence of a necessary uniform bound for the sequence of associated inf-sup constants.

Furthermore, the PI's ascertained the Hadamard wellposedness and stability properties of solutions to a certain compressible flow-structure PDE model arising in aeroelasticity. These systems basically describe the flutter phenomenon - i.e., deformations and oscillations consequent to elastic structures such as airplane wings being subjected to air flows. The deformations on the elastic interface (wing) yield so-called “material derivative” boundary conditions (BC) and “material derivative-free” BC. Under different cases we obtained semigroup wellposedness and strong/exponential decay of solutions to these coupled systems. The PI's findings could potentially allow for the investigation of more realistic engineering applications of multi-flow structure interaction phenomena: in particular, the prediction of aeronautical hazards such as Supercooled Large Droplet (SLD) icing accretion on an aircraft wing or airfoil due to multiflow effects.

The PI's also investigated stability properties for solutions of PDE systems which govern acoustic flow within a 3-D chamber coupled to a 2-D elastic plate under thermal effects on one side of the chamber. These PDE models describe acoustic environments which are adversely affected by the structural vibrations created by mechanical phenomena such as aircraft, ships, general ventilation and combustion systems. For these systems the PI's obtained sharp energy decay rates of the solutions. These stability results constitute an improvement over those in the previous literature as they were obtained imposing any additional (possibly physically unrealistic) feedback dissipation on the "hard" walls of the chamber domain.

Moreover, the PI's considered a multilayered fluid-structure interaction system (FSI), wherein the coupling of the 3-D fluid (mammalian blood flow) and 3-D elastic (structural vascular wall) components is realized via an additional 2-D elastic system on the boundary interface. The regularizing effects of the underlying fluid dissipation and the coupling at the boundary interface provided existence/uniqueness and asymptotic stability of solutions. These qualitative results of the PI's could yield a better mathematical understanding of various vascular pathologies, such as aneurysms or other wall vascular defects.

The results obtained by the PI's have had implications in Graduate and Undergraduate training and research: One of the PI’s Graduate Students wrote and defended her Ph.D. thesis which deals with the continuous analysis and numerical simulation of a boundary controllability problem for a nonlinear vibrating plate equation, her thesis work necessarily appealing to the techniques developed during the Project Terms. In addition, one of the PI’s current Graduate Students has made Conference presentations on her ongoing thesis work on stability of structural acoustic flows. Furthermore, during the Project Terms, the Co-PI conducted undergraduate research with three Honors Undergraduates at Iowa State University. In particular, she directed them in studies of controllability problems for certain finite dimensional ODE systems. These controlled ODE systems are truncations of the PDE systems that are used to model structure-fluid and structural acoustic phenomena. Accordingly, in the course of training these Undergraduates she intrroduced needed material from Numerical Linear Algebra.

The PI's disseminated their obtained Project results and nteracted with team members of Center for Multiphase Flow Research and Education (CoMFRE) of Iowa State University. The Co-PI has been a CoMFRE team member since 2019. CoMFRE is active in visualizing complex multiphase flow and flow-interaction models, for the purpose of research and technology transfer. The PI's presented their project outcomes via the CoMFRE seminar series, thereby and increasing awareness of the utility of fluid-structure interaction mathematical research in industrial applications.


Last Modified: 11/10/2021
Modified by: George Avalos
